citation.article-title: Lactobacillus sucicola sp. nov., a motile lactic acid bacterium isolated from oak tree (Quercus sp.) sap
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Lactobacillus sucicola sp. nov.
Lactobacillus sucicola [su′ci.co′la. L. n. sucus sap; L. suff. -cola (from L. n. incola) inhabitant, dweller; N.L. n. sucicola a sap-dweller].
Cells are Gram-positive rods measuring 1.0×2.0–3.0 μm.
Cells occur singly or in pairs and are motile by means of peritrichous flagella.
Colonies are white, smooth and 2 mm diameter on MRS agar plates incubated at 30 °C for 3–4 days.
No gas is produced from d-glucose.
l-Lactic acid is produced from glucose as the main end product.

Acid is produced from d-glucose, d-fructose, d-galactose, d-mannose, melibiose, sucrose, d-salicin, trehalose, d-mannitol and sorbitol, but not from l-arabinose, d-ribose, d-xylose, gluconate, rhamnose, cellobiose, lactose, melezitose or starch.
Acid production from maltose and raffinose is variable between strains.
Cells grow at 15 and 45 °C, but not at 10 or 50 °C.
Growth is not observed in GYP broth containing 5 % (w/v) NaCl.
The cell-wall peptidoglycan contains meso-diaminopimelic acid as the diagnostic diamino acid.
The DNA G+C content ranges from 37 to 38 mol% (type strain, 38 mol%).
The type strain, NRIC 0736T (=JCM 15457T=DSM 21376T), was isolated from the sap of an oak (Quercus sp.) from Awashima Island, Kagawa Prefecture, Japan.
Additional strains were also isolated from the oak sap.
